text: In our fourth year of producing , we can report the highest levels yet for data
label: BODY

text: availability across priority humanitarian operations. These gains can be attributed to the commitment of
label: BODY

text: organizations to sharing and maintaining their data publicly. There was also strong demand for data about the
label: BODY

text: world’s largest humanitarian crises, from the war in Ukraine to drought and food insecurity in the Horn of Africa.
label: BODY

text: Our understanding of data availability and use comes from managing the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX), an
label: BODY

text: open platform for finding and sharing data across crises and organizations.1 In 2022, HDX was used by 1.5 million
label: BODY

text: people in 233 countries and territories, an increase of 8 percent compared with 2021. Organizations added 3,700
label: BODY

text: new and updated datasets, bringing the total to more than 20,400 datasets, which were downloaded over 1.8
label: BODY

text: million times. Although HDX includes data about all countries in the world, we concentrate here on 25 locations
label: BODY

text: with humanitarian response plans (HRPs).2 In 2022, 32 percent of all datasets downloaded from HDX were
label: BODY

text: At the start of 2023, we estimate that 73 percent of relevant, complete crisis data is available across 25
label: BODY

text: humanitarian operations, based on the analysis of the HDX Data Grids (see criteria below). If we add the data that
label: BODY

text: is relevant but incomplete, the total is 93 percent. This leaves 7 percent of categories with data that does not
label: BODY

text: meet the criteria or with no data. The 25 Data Grids include 459 unique datasets, with a range of 13-22 datasets
label: BODY

text: HRPs are prepared by UN Humanitarian Country Teams in locations where there is an ongoing humanitarian emergency. HRPs are generally
label: BODY

text: prepared annually, and outline an overall strategy and specific activities for each humanitarian cluster or sector.
label: BODY

text: We use Mixpanel, a third-party analytics service, to understand the behavior of users on the HDX platform. We do not send identifying information
label: BODY

text: This report contains details on the data available for each location, category and sub-category covered in the Data
label: BODY

text: Grids as of 31 December 2022. It includes a country deep-dive for South Sudan and showcases the work of the
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team (HOT) on community mapping. It also provides examples of how climate
label: BODY

text: impact data is being used to predict the impacts of a hazard on lives and livelihoods and trigger actions to
label: BODY

text: The HDX Data Grids narrow the focus within each HRP location to a limited set of foundational data needed to
label: BODY

text: understand a humanitarian context. They provide a comparable way to assess data availability across locations and
label: BODY

text: categories and are the basis for the analysis in this report.
label: BODY

text: The Data Grids include six categories: aﬀected people; coordination and context; food security and nutrition;
label: BODY

text: geography and infrastructure; health and education; and population and socio-economy. (See Annex A for definitions.)
label: BODY

text: Data may be included in a Data Grid if it is relevant to the category and sub-national. The data is considered ‘complete’
label: BODY

text: if it has broad geographic coverage, is shared in a commonly used format, and is up-to-date. If any of those criteria are
label: BODY

text: not met, then it is considered ‘incomplete’. The sub-category is complete if it includes at least one dataset that is
label: BODY

text: complete. If the sub-category contains only incomplete datasets, then that sub-category is considered incomplete. A
label: BODY

text: sub-category is empty if no data meets the above criteria or the data does not exist on HDX. (See Annex B for the Data
label: BODY

text: In 2022, HDX maintained Data Grids for 25 locations and 20 sub-categories. The number of locations decreased by two
label: BODY

text: from 2021 given that Zimbabwe and Pakistan no longer had humanitarian response plans in 2022. Two sub-categories
label: BODY

text: were removed – transportation status and aﬀected areas – and one was added for climate impact. (See Annex C for
label: BODY

text: We recognize the valuable contributions of all data-sharing organizations publishing data on HDX, and in
label: BODY

text: particular the 18 organizations that populate the Data Grids, with reference to 175 data sources. Datasets
label: BODY

text: included in the Data Grids are downloaded almost five times more than the average dataset on HDX.4 Trusted
label: BODY

text: partnerships and focused advocacy efforts have led to many new or updated datasets in the Data Grids this year,
label: BODY

text: • Global malnutrition prevalence rates disaggregated by province in Afghanistan, contributed by OCHA
label: BODY

text: • The number of displaced people by sub-prefecture in the Central African Republic (CAR), validated by the
label: BODY

text: Commission des Mouvements de Population and shared by OCHA CAR.6
label: BODY

text: • The impact of floods with disruption to aﬀected populations, destroyed infrastructure and vegetation in Niger,
label: BODY

text: contributed by OCHA Niger and sourced to the Ministère de l'Action Humanitaire et de la Gestion des
label: BODY

text: • Education facilities by type and location in Somalia, compiled by UNICEF and contributed by OCHA Somalia.8
label: BODY

text: • Sub-national sex and age disaggregated population statistics for Sudan with updated projections for 2022,
label: BODY

text: contributed by UNFPA and sourced to the Central Bureau of Statistics for Sudan.9
label: BODY

text: There were dozens of high-value datasets available on HDX throughout 2022 that go beyond the scope of the
label: BODY

text: Data Grids. A few examples include:
label: BODY

text: • The list of voyages completed under the Black Sea Grain Initiative since August 2022, compiled and shared by
label: BODY

text: • Acute food insecurity estimates, cross-border trade and staple food prices for 37 countries, shared by the
label: BODY

text: • Historical typhoon impact data covering the number of people aﬀected and homes damaged from 2014 to
label: BODY

text: 2020 in the Philippines, compiled and shared by the Netherlands Red Cross.
label: BODY

text: • High-resolution population density maps and demographic estimates and the Facebook Social
label: BODY

text: Connectedness Index, covering dozens of countries and shared by Meta.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: In 2022, Data Grid datasets were downloaded, on average, 585 times each whereas the average dataset on HDX was downloaded 116 times.
label: BODY

text: • The availability of core data for priority humanitarian operations is at its highest levels in the past four years,
label: BODY

text: but gaps remain with climate impact data, acute malnutrition prevalence and access constraints, among
label: BODY

text: • Since 2019, when the Data Grids were first introduced on HDX, we have seen an increase in data completeness
label: BODY

text: from 54 percent to 73 percent in locations with humanitarian response plans. The categories with no data
label: BODY

text: have fallen from 25 percent to 7 percent (see chart below).
label: BODY

text: • These gains can be attributed to the strong commitment of organizations to sharing and maintaining their
label: BODY

text: data publicly through the HDX platform.
label: BODY

text: • There was strong demand for data about the world’s largest humanitarian crises, from the war in Ukraine to
label: BODY

text: drought and food insecurity in the Horn of Africa. Data covering Ukraine, Ethiopia and Nigeria was the most
label: BODY

text: • In 2022, HDX was used by 1.5 million people in 233 countries and territories. Around 1.8 million datasets were
label: BODY

text: • We estimate that 73 percent of relevant, complete crisis data is available across 25 locations with
label: BODY

text: humanitarian operations, based on the analysis of the HDX Data Grids. If we add the data that is relevant but
label: BODY

text: incomplete, the total is 93 percent. This leaves about 7 percent of the Data Grids with no data.
label: BODY

text: • Over two dozen new organizations joined HDX in 2022, bringing the total to almost 300 organizations.
label: BODY

text: Eighteen organizations contribute data that is included in the Data Grids.
label: BODY

text: • The 25 Data Grids included 459 unique datasets, with a range of 13-22 datasets per location. Datasets included
label: BODY

text: in the Data Grids are downloaded almost five times more than the average dataset on HDX.
label: BODY

text: • South Sudan, Afghanistan and Somalia have the most complete Data Grids. Venezuela, Syria and Libya are the
label: BODY

text: countries with the largest data gaps.
label: BODY

text: • The most complete Data Grid sub-categories are funding, administrative divisions, baseline population, IDPs,
label: BODY

text: refugees and persons of concern, and food prices, owing to the work of OCHA, UNFPA, IOM, UNHCR, and WFP.
label: BODY

text: • Humanitarian crises are dynamic and so is the data needed to understand them. The availability and
label: BODY

text: completeness of data will fluctuate year-to-year as new data requirements come into focus.
label: BODY

text: • A priority for 2023 will be a continued focus on climate impact data, which is essential for understanding and
label: BODY

text: predicting the future impacts of hazards on vulnerable populations. We will also explore implementing data
label: BODY

text: quality grades or scores for some datasets included in the Data Grids.
label: BODY

text: 4. COMPLETENESS BY LOCATION, CATEGORY AND SUB-CATEGORY
label: HH2

text: By the end of 2022, there were improvements in data availability across location, category and sub-category. Six
label: BODY

text: countries – Afghanistan, CAR, Nigeria, Somalia, South Sudan and Sudan – no longer have any sub-categories with
label: BODY

text: missing data, although some data remains incomplete in geographic coverage or frequency. The geography and
label: BODY

text: infrastructure category become more complete with data added on populated places for a number of countries.
label: BODY

text: Overall, the sub-categories with no data decreased from 11 percent to 7 percent year on year.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: South Sudan (100 percent), Afghanistan (95 percent) and Somalia (90 percent) are the countries with the highest
label: BODY

text: levels of data completeness. The next most-complete locations for data are the Central African Republic
label: BODY

text: Venezuela (40 percent of the sub-categories with no data), Syria (20 percent of the sub-categories with no data)
label: BODY

text: and Libya (15 percent of the sub-categories with no data) are the countries with the largest data gaps.
label: BODY

text: The most complete categories are population and socio-economy (94 percent), aﬀected people (86 percent) and
label: BODY

text: food security and nutrition (81 percent). Health and education is the least complete category at 46 percent, owing
label: BODY

text: to incomplete data for the location of health and education facilities. The most popular category, in terms of total
label: BODY

text: dataset downloads, is geography and infrastructure.
label: BODY

text: A total of 459 unique datasets are included in the 25 Data Grids. Each Data Grid includes between 13 to 22 datasets.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: The most complete sub-categories are funding, administrative divisions and baseline population (all at 100
label: BODY

text: percent) followed by IDPs, refugees and persons of concern, and food prices (all at 96 percent), owing to the
label: BODY

text: contributions of OCHA, UNFPA, IOM, UNHCR and WFP. Education facilities (32 percent), airports (36 percent) and
label: BODY

text: humanitarian access (40 percent) are the most challenging sub-categories to complete.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org

label: BODY

text: This view of the Data Grids also shows where data is consistently shared across all locations but is considered
label: BODY

text: incomplete. This is the case for conflict events data (political violence, civilian-targeting and demonstrations)
label: BODY

text: which is shared on a weekly basis for each country. As of June 2023, ACLED made subnational conflict data at the
label: BODY

text: second administrative division (Admin2) level for countries with an active humanitarian response plan available
label: BODY

text: for direct download on HDX. The addition of these subnational data files, updated weekly, make the conflict
label: BODY

text: events subcategory 100 percent complete as of June 2023, which should be reflected in next year's report. All
label: BODY

text: disaggregated event-level conflict data remain publicly accessible through the ACLED website.
label: BODY

text: South Sudan : Operational Presence  OCHA South Sudan
label: BODY

text: Current IATI aid activities in South Sudan
label: BODY

text: South Sudan: Flood Data  OCHA South Sudan
label: BODY

text: There has been steady progress with the South Sudan Data Grid over the past year owing to the engagement of
label: BODY

text: the OCHA Country Oﬀice and humanitarian partners. South Sudan became the first location to reach 100 percent
label: BODY

text: completeness, up from 76 percent complete last year.
label: BODY

text: The Data Grid includes 20 unique datasets shared by nine organizations. Together, these datasets were
label: BODY

text: downloaded 8,348 times in 2022. The most popular dataset was the administrative boundaries for the country.
label: BODY

text: Another sought-afer dataset was the number of people aﬀected by flooding, by state and county, over the
label: BODY

text: previous two years, which is included in the climate impact sub-category.
label: BODY

text: South Sudan - Data on forcibly displaced populations
label: BODY

text: and stateless persons  UNHCR - The UN Refugee Agency

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: The Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team, known by its acronym HOT, supports humanitarian action and
label: BODY

text: community development through open mapping. When disaster strikes anywhere in the world, HOT is able to
label: BODY

text: mobilize thousands of volunteers who come together online and on the ground to create open data that enables
label: BODY

text: disaster responders to reach those in need.
label: BODY

text: The data is derived from a crowdsourcing model that leverages OpenStreetMap (OSM), a free, open source,
label: BODY

text: editable map of the world. The data is contributed to OSM in one of three ways:
label: BODY

text: • In-person, mobile data collection that is focused on the location of specific infrastructure, such as education
label: BODY

text: • Remote sensing and digitization from satellite imagery or unmanned aerial vehicles to create building and
label: BODY

text: • Importing existing datasets from governments and organizations.
label: BODY

text: Given their commitment to open source data and tools, HOT became one of the first organizations to join HDX
label: BODY

text: when it launched in 2014. Since then, they have added over 4,400 datasets covering 249 countries and territories,
label: BODY

text: which currently accounts for about 20 percent of all data on HDX. The data includes the essential ingredients for
label: BODY

text: map making: road networks; populated places; airport, railways and port locations; education and health
label: BODY

text: facilities; and rivers and waterways. These details are critical for humanitarians to understand the physical
label: BODY

text: geography and infrastructure of a country, and this data is consistently among the most downloaded on HDX.
label: BODY

text: The humanitarian open mapping community, which is currently estimated to be around 423,000 people from
label: BODY

text: around the world,   is continuously updating the data on OpenStreetMap. The HOT and HDX teams realized early
label: BODY

text: on that it would be impossible to keep the datasets on HDX up-to-date without an automated process. In 2016,
label: BODY

text: we worked together to build an extension to the HOT Export Tool – called the HOT Bot   – which sends the data to
label: BODY

text: HDX on a regular cycle. This eliminates the complex task of configuring a custom export in the HOT Export Tool
label: BODY

text: and pre-packages the data in common GIS data formats broken down by country and region.
label: BODY

text: The datasets exported by HOT are included in the Data Grids if they are deemed to be the best available source for
label: BODY

text: a sub-category. This determination is made by the HDX team in collaboration with the Information Management
label: BODY

text: Working Group in each country. In 2022, data attributed to HOT was included in the Data Grids for nine countries
label: BODY

text: covering three sub-categories – airports, populated places and roads.
label: BODY

text: AFGHANISTAN  AIRPORTS, POPULATED PLACES AND ROADS
label: HH3

text: Open mapping data is not included in the Data Grids in cases when it is too sensitive to share (e.g., the location of
label: BODY

text: health facilities in an active conflict), or when there is a more complete version of the data available from an
label: BODY

text: For HOT, data quality is a primary concern. Additions and improvements are contributed by a large number of
label: BODY

text: partners in the humanitarian and development space, as well as commercial partners using OSM data in their
label: BODY

text: workflows and products. To complement existing data validation, HOT and HDX are working to provide additional
label: BODY

text: insights into factors such as data accuracy and completeness.
label: BODY

text: In 2022, the data exported by HOT to HDX was downloaded almost 67,000 times by users in 194 countries and
label: BODY

text: territories. Road network data for Afghanistan, Ethiopia and Pakistan were among the most popular. Datasets
label: BODY

text: shared by HOT will continue to be in high demand at the onset of a new crisis, providing first responders with the
label: BODY

text: geographical awareness that is essential for humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: We are grateful to Humanitarian OpenStreetMap for being a steadfast data sharing partner. Visit their site    to
label: BODY

text: learn more about becoming part of the humanitarian open mapping community and explore how to request,
label: BODY

text: create and use geospatial data for development and humanitarian purposes.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Out of the 293 organizations    sharing data on HDX, 18 contribute data that is included in the Data Grids, with
label: BODY

text: reference to 175 data sources. These 18 organizations are consistently among the top organizations on HDX with
label: BODY

text: the most datasets downloaded. OCHA is counted as a single organization even though over 30 field oﬀices    and
label: BODY

text: two entities at Headquarters contribute data to HDX. In total, OCHA field oﬀices contributed 214 datasets or 43
label: BODY

text: percent of all data in the Data Grids.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: United Nations Oﬀice for the Coordination of Humanitarian Aﬀairs
label: BODY

text: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
label: BODY

text: An organization on HDX can be a legal entity or an informal group and may be listed as the source or the contributor of the dataset. The entities listed in
label: BODY

text: this section have created organizations on HDX and manage their data directly. Although most organizations are both the source and contributor for the
label: BODY

text: data, there are cases where this varies. For instance, as part of its coordination role, OCHA aggregates and shares data on humanitarian needs but the data
label: BODY

text: This covers UNICEF oﬀices in two countries: DRC and South Sudan.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: The most significant change to the Data Grids in 2022 was the inclusion of a new sub-category for climate impact
label: BODY

text: data. This data should contain the current and historical impacts of climate events relating to floods, droughts
label: BODY

text: and storms, as well as their location, date and impact on aﬀected populations, infrastructure and/or vegetation.
label: BODY

text: By the end of the year, this sub-category was 68 percent complete with data missing for seven countries with
label: BODY

text: With the climate crisis intensifying emergencies around the world, humanitarians are increasingly having to
label: BODY

text: incorporate climate data and forecasts into their analysis and planning. This is especially the case for anticipatory
label: BODY

text: action, which relies on models to predict the impacts of a hazard on lives and livelihoods and trigger actions to
label: BODY

text: Since 2019, the Centre has supported OCHA’s anticipatory action pilots for various hazards in twelve countries.
label: BODY

text: This has ranged from drought in Chad and Somalia to floods in Nepal and Bangladesh. Our technical support
label: BODY

text: involves conducting historical analysis of the hazard and its impact, assessing available models and forecasts,
label: BODY

text: and designing trigger mechanisms for the release of funds. By the end of 2022, the UN Central Emergency
label: BODY

text: Response Fund had released $89 million    in funding for anticipatory action based on trigger mechanisms
label: BODY

text: developed by the Centre and OCHA oﬀices.
label: BODY

text: Three types of climate data are used to build, evaluate and validate trigger mechanisms:
label: BODY

text: •  data on what is likely to happen next (the forecast)
label: BODY

text: The data that is most ofen missing for this analysis is the impact data. Without it, we are not able to model the
label: BODY

text: As an example, in Niger we used household survey data to understand the impact of seasonal rainfall levels on
label: BODY

text: livelihoods. Once we understood this, we were able to use seasonal rainfall forecasts to inform humanitarian
label: BODY

text: partners about the likely impact of a below average season. Similarly, in the Philippines    we worked with the
label: BODY

text: Netherlands Red Cross to use historical typhoon track and rainfall data to train a model that estimates housing
label: BODY

text: damage caused by typhoons. This model is now being used to estimate the expected impact based on typhoon
label: BODY

text: forecasts provided by meteorological institutions. A historical typhoon impact dataset,    covering 2014 to 2020,
label: BODY

text: By the end of 2022, eighteen climate impact datasets had been added to HDX and the Data Grids, in collaboration
label: BODY

text: with OCHA oﬀices and partners. A few examples include:
label: BODY

text: • Mozambique: Data on the number of people aﬀected by cyclones at the district level from 2016 to 2022, shared
label: BODY

text: by OCHA Mozambique and produced by Instituto Nacional de Gestão e Redução do Risco de Desastres.
label: BODY

text: • Mali: Data on the number of people aﬀected, houses destroyed, water and sanitation infrastructure damaged
label: BODY

text: and livestock lost as the results of seasonal floods, shared and maintained by OCHA Mali.
label: BODY

text: • Burundi: Data on the impact from floods and heavy rains on populations, infrastructure and/or vegetation,
label: BODY

text: shared by IOM via OCHA Burundi.
label: BODY

text: The $89 million has been allocated for drought in Niger, Somalia and Ethiopia; for flooding in Bangladesh, South Sudan and Nepal; and for
label: BODY

text: cholera in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
label: BODY

text: Beyond the Data Grids, we are also looking to make a wider set of climate data more accessible to the HDX
label: BODY

text: community. For example, WFP recently shared earth observation datasets    on rainfall and vegetation health
label: BODY

text: covering 33 countries with either a humanitarian response plan or an anticipatory action framework. With this
label: BODY

text: data, humanitarians can assess current drought conditions and also analyze historical trends to anticipate the
label: BODY

text: Despite this progress, climate impact data remains scarce for certain types of climate shocks and locations and
label: BODY

text: the historical time period is ofen limited. In the year ahead, we plan to share practical guidance on how to
label: BODY

text: interpret and use common forecasts, such as seasonal rainfall forecasts or riverine flood projections. And we are
label: BODY

text: developing tools    to make it easier for humanitarians to use climate data.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: We will continue to update the Data Grids throughout the year as organizations share new, relevant data. The
label: BODY

text: current status for each location is always available on HDX, both on the relevant location page and on the
label: BODY

text: Overview of Data Grids page.    As part of our internal Data Grid Governance Group, we will regularly review the
label: BODY

text: categories and sub-categories to see if they should be removed or expanded.
label: BODY

text: A priority for 2023 will be a continued focus on climate impact data, which is essential for understanding and
label: BODY

text: predicting the future impacts of hazards on vulnerable populations. We will also explore implementing data
label: BODY

text: quality grades or scores for some datasets included in the Data Grids.
label: BODY

text: We welcome feedback on possible improvements. Please be in touch with questions or comments at
label: BODY

text: ANNEX A: DATA GRID SUB-CATEGORY DEFINITIONS
label: HH2

text: Tabular data of the number of displaced people by location. Locations can be administrative divisions
label: BODY

text: or other locations (such as camps) if an additional dataset defining those locations is also available.
label: BODY

text: Tabular data of the number of refugees and persons of concern either in the country or originating
label: BODY

text: from the country disaggregated by their current location. Locations can be administrative divisions or
label: BODY

text: other locations (such as camps) if an additional dataset defining those locations is also available or if
label: BODY

text: the locations' coordinates are defined in the tabular data.
label: BODY

text: Tabular data of the number of displaced people who have returned.
label: BODY

text: Tabular data of the number of people in need of humanitarian assistance by location and
label: BODY

text: List of organizations working on humanitarian issues, by humanitarian cluster/sector and
label: BODY

text: Tabular data listing the amount of funding provided by humanitarian cluster/sector.
label: BODY

text: Vector data or tabular data with coordinates describing the location, date and type of conflict event.
label: BODY

text: Tabular or vector data describing the location of natural hazards, permissions, active fighting or other
label: BODY

text: access constraints that impact the delivery of humanitarian interventions.
label: BODY

text: Tabular or vector data containing current and historical impacts of climate events relating to floods,
label: BODY

text: droughts and storms. The data should specify the location of the event, date of the event, and contain
label: BODY

text: at least one indicator of impact such as spatial extent of event, disruption to aﬀected populations,
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: representing population or percentage of population by IPC/CH phase and administrative division.
label: BODY

text: Tabular data specifying the global acute malnutrition (GAM) or severe acute malnutrition (SAM) rate
label: BODY

text: Time series prices for common food commodities at a set of locations.
label: BODY

text: Vector geographic data describing the sub-national administrative divisions of a location, usually a
label: BODY

text: country, including the names and unique identifiers, usually p-codes, of each administrative division.
label: BODY

text: To be considered ‘complete’, and included here, the humanitarian community working in the location
label: BODY

text: has to have endorsed a preferred set of administrative boundaries as the Common Operational
label: BODY

text: Vector data or tabular data with coordinates representing the location of populated places (cities,
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: the type of facility (school, university, etc.).

label: BODY

text: ANNEX B: INCLUSION OF DATA IN THE DATA GRIDS
label: HH2

text: Data Grid curation involves the careful evaluation of datasets on HDX for inclusion in one or more of the
label: BODY

text: sub-categories in accordance with our standard criteria. The HDX team conducts this evaluation when a dataset is
label: BODY

text: newly added or updated on HDX.
label: BODY

text: The HDX team supports the Data Grids in three ways:
label: BODY

text: 1. Reviewing whether any dataset on HDX could be added to a Data Grid;
label: BODY

text: 2. Conducting targeted outreach with humanitarian organizations to find relevant datasets; and
label: BODY

text: 3. Identifying potential datasets with partners in the research community, academia and/or government
label: BODY

text: The first step in determining whether a dataset should be included in a Data Grid is to check whether the dataset
label: BODY

text: meets the thematic requirement defined in Annex A. Datasets that are not considered relevant are automatically
label: BODY

text: The second step is to determine if the dataset is sub-national. To fulfill this requirement the data must be
label: BODY

text: disaggregated to at least the first administrative division. If the data is only available at the national level, it is
label: BODY

text: typically excluded. The sub-national requirement has been partially or completely waived for three datasets:
label: BODY

text: UNHCR’s data on forcibly displaced populations and stateless persons; OCHA FTS’s requirements and funding
label: BODY

text: The third step is to assess whether a thematically relevant, sub-national data set is complete or incomplete. A
label: BODY

text: dataset is considered complete if it satisfies all of the following criteria:
label: BODY

text: 2. Available in commonly used formats; and
label: BODY

text: If the dataset does not satisfy one or more of these criteria, it is considered incomplete.
label: BODY

text: Finally, the dataset is compared against existing datasets for that location to determine if it should be added to
label: BODY

text: the Data Grid. If the sub-category is empty, or if the data would complement other datasets in a sub-category, the
label: BODY

text: HDX team will add it to the Data Grid. A complementary dataset is one that adds unique and useful information to
label: BODY

text: The IATI datasets are a good example of a complementary dataset as they add unique and useful information to
label: BODY

text: the 3W sub-category. Another example is a dataset that provides data for a geographic area not covered by the
label: BODY

text: existing dataset. If there is already a complete dataset available for the sub-category, the HDX team will reach out
label: BODY

text: to in-country partners to determine which dataset is being used operationally and that dataset will be included in
label: BODY

text: The sub-category is considered complete if it has at least one complete dataset available for the sub-category. If
label: BODY

text: the sub-category contains only incomplete datasets, then that sub-category is considered incomplete. Overall
label: BODY

text: category completeness refers to the proportion of sub-categories in the category that are complete. Similarly,
label: BODY

text: completeness for a location refers to the proportion of sub-categories that are complete in the location.
label: BODY

text: Sub-categories are considered empty if no datasets on HDX meet the above-mentioned criteria. In general, data
label: BODY

text: can be missing for three reasons:
label: BODY

text: See Annex C of The State of Open Humanitarian Data 2022 for the information on the decision-making process for sub-national dataset waivers:
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: 1. It is not collected (e.g., because nobody is present to do so, because it is unsafe to access areas to collect
label: BODY

text: it, because it requires investment and resources that are not available, or because nobody prioritizes it
label: BODY

text: 2. It is collected but not publicly shared (e.g., because the collecting organization does not have an open
label: BODY

text: data policy, because the data is sensitive and should not be shared, because the collecting entity fears
label: BODY

text: sharing the data with actors they do not know and trust, or because of a lack of resources to clean and
label: BODY

text: 3. It is collected and shared but is not shared on HDX, or known about by the HDX team.
label: BODY

text: The criteria for evaluating completeness for relevant, sub-national data are detailed below:
label: BODY

text: Does the data have broad geographic coverage with explicit location information?
label: HH3

text: •  Is the dataset geographically comprehensive, or as comprehensive as possible? If the dataset is
label: BODY

text: disaggregated by administrative divisions, does it cover all of them? If it does not, is the meaning of a
label: BODY

text: missing administrative division defined in the metadata? If there is no comprehensive list to compare
label: BODY

text: against (for example, with spontaneous displacement locations), does the dataset make it clear if it
label: BODY

text: attempts to be comprehensive or not?
label: BODY

text: •  Are location references defined? The dataset should contain explicit geographic data (i.e., Geographic
label: BODY

text: Information System data or tabular data with latitude and longitude fields). If not, the dataset should be
label: BODY

text: joinable to an available dataset that defines those locations.
label: BODY

text: Is the data in commonly-used formats?
label: HH3

text: •  Is it stored in a common file format? We include CSV, XLS, XLSX, SHP, GEOJSON, etc. Formats like GPKG
label: BODY

text: and others that are more diﬀicult for the typical humanitarian data specialist would be marked
label: BODY

text: •  Is the data tidy? Field names and data rows should be easy to determine. There should not be sub-total
label: BODY

text: rows interspersed with data rows. The required data for the category should be in a single table on the
label: BODY

text: same tab. For tabular data with coordinates, the x and y columns (usually longitude and latitude) should
label: BODY

text: be in decimal degree format and separated into two columns.
label: BODY

text: •  Has the dataset become out of date? Depending on how frequently the dataset is expected to be
label: BODY

text: updated, the HDX team considers the age of the data and whether the dataset should have been
label: BODY

text: ANNEX C: CHANGES TO THE DATA GRIDS
label: HH2

text: Over the last year, we have continued to solicit feedback from OCHA field oﬀices and our partners to ensure that
label: BODY

text: the sub-category definitions and curation criteria reflect data needs in humanitarian operations. The Data Grid
label: BODY

text: Governance Group discusses the feedback that we receive and makes decisions around changes to the Data
label: BODY

text: In 2022, the Data Grid Governance Group met three times and approved the following changes:
label: BODY

text: 1) Adding a sub-category for climate impact
label: HH3

text: We expanded the Data Grids to include a new sub-category for climate impact which covers current and historical
label: BODY

text: hazards and their impact on people, infrastructure and/or vegetation. Read more about this decision in our blog
label: BODY

text: 2) Removing sub-categories for transportation status and aﬀected areas
label: HH3

text: a. Transportation status: The diﬀerence between the transportation status and roads sub-categories was
label: BODY

text: ofen unclear. In more than 35 percent of locations, the same dataset was used for both sub-categories.
label: BODY

text: b. Aﬀected areas: The definition for the aﬀected areas sub-category focused on the type and/or severity of
label: BODY

text: geographical impacts. This was interpreted diﬀerently across locations, making it an inconsistent
label: BODY

text: measure for data availability. When the sub-category was complete, it was a mix of data on the impact of
label: BODY

text: climate events and the severity estimates included in a Humanitarian Needs Overview dataset.
label: BODY
